title: Thumb Roller Hook for Dial Caliper

description.text: This is a replacement part for the thumb roller hook that broke on one of my dial calipers. I made the part by injection molding polypropylene. I included the model files used to make the aluminum mold. I don't know how often these things break but I couldn't find a direct replacement for mine. I did see some company selling a similar part that might have worked for ~$8. I think I bought the caliper for about $15. Additional information about my injection molding process can be found at http://www.scorchworks.com/Injection_molding/injection_molding.html

I used a CNC mill to make aluminum molds and injection molded polypropylene to make this part.  The model is designed so that the mold can be milled with a 1/16 end mill.  I used a Dremel 1/16 carbide grout removal bit for the bottom half mold because my standard length 1/16 end mill was not long enough.  I used a 1/16 ball end mill on the top side to make it look nicer.   The models for the molds do not include the gates for injecting the plastic.  I milled the gates in manually after the main section of the mold was made.

comments.text: Nice work, always wanted my own injection molder, not got around to it yet :)
comments.author: andrewar

comments.text: Polyurethane (e.g. from Smooth-On) can be done nicely on a budget - I shoot the liquid pre-polymer in to the mould with a syringe (cut the threaded shell portion off the luer lock and mill the gate to fit the luer tightly) and it works well.

title: Stronghold for Overlord- Toolholder for Overlord 3D Printer

description.text:
Hi, My first design in thingiverse. I've got a Overlord 3D printer this year. As a delta printer, it's quite tall and shapes like a 'Hexagon castle'. So I design a 'Hexagon stronghold' for this castle, as a a tool container used in 3D tool. It can hold most commonly-used tools as follows:
  • One Glue Stick.( for hot bed)
  • Screwdriver and 5 bits. ( for adjustment of the plate)
  • a Vernier Caliper.(Measure height when bed leveling)
  • a pliers.(for Cutting filament when reloading)
    5.a shovel（for removing model)
    • With this, you can find a home for all your Overlord tools. Hopes you like it. If you can read Chinese, you can click http://www.dfrobot.com.cn/community/forum.php?mod=viewthread&tid=13386&extra=page%3D1 for original message.

description.text: The use of a touch plate with any CNC machine is a must. However, the touch plate is used only when setting up the stock and the rooter height, after that it is no longer needed and it is in the way. As such, and in the spirit of the End Stop Mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1244604 I made, I created a similar cover of the other end of the X axis to have banana plug sockets in order to remove the probe when no longer needed. The socket for the holes is 7.5mm. There is also the PG7 cable gland at the top to let the wires out to the CNC board. Enjoy. Edit, added new pictures upon request.

title: Addon to raspberry pi case for LEDs and shutdown button

description.text:
A box that will fit onto the excellent raspberry pi 2 box (thing 9227400), to house the following items: 1 push button.
5 LEDs. The box is secured by two of the existing screws. I made this in an attempt to keep my prototype circuit tidy and secure.
The button initiates a shutdown. The single LED is connected to GPIO15 (RxDO) and allows the status of the raspberry PI to be identified at a glance.
The 4 LEDs are wired to GPIO06,13,19 and 26 and are used for me to test my code.

description.text: Based on Sandy Noble's Polargraph: http://polargraph.co.uk This is the first pass at a printable gondola for a Polargraph. It works, but it could use some tweaks. Anyone looking to improve it: the lower section arms are a little thin, and the spot for the captive nut isn't exactly sized right. I'd also beef up the upper chain mounts, as there's not much plastic outside the hole. The motor brackets and pulleys I'm using can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12403 Lots more photos of the whole process here:

Print it out, no assembly required.   Uses an M3 bolt to adjust the grip on the pen, and another to mount some kind of weight on it.   You could use washers, I used quarters with holes drilled in them.

author: Arnaud29

description.text:
The dimensions of this box mod are: 56x25x88 mm. A suggestion: print it with ABS because PLA do not resist for this kind of usage. To mount the box mod u need:
  • 10 magnets 3x1 mm;
  • 1 ON/OFF switch (http://fave.co/2boIKAN);
  • a 12 mm push button;
  • a mosftet IRLB3034 (http://fave.co/2bsiYPl)
  • battery contact (whatever u want, there 74 mm of space for the battery) (Keystone 5209 > http://fave.co/2bskiBT)
    • For the wiring i used the scheme that u can see in the shots.
    This box mod is for two 18650 in serie (not parallel).

  • two different connector hole (10 and 12 mm);
  • two different door: with or without direct access to the on-off switch.
    • Remember, for YOUR SAFETY, to put off the box mod when u don'use it. Good luck. The box mod in the shot is printed with a Zortrax M200 at 140 microns.

title: Nanxiao Chinese Bamboo Flute
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a precise copy of my Chinese end-blown Nanxiao or Dongxiao bamboo flute. It could be considered as the Chinese version of the shakuhachi. You may find the fingering chart here: http://www.goamcan.com/imports/How-to-play-xiao.html, chose the 8 hole version which matches this flute.
I supply an stl file of the entire flute in one piece, one file in which the flute is cut in 7 pieces, as well as the 7 pieces as individual files. I put a joint between the mouth piece and the second piece. It may require some polishing. The other pieces can be glued together by epoxy.
Furthermore, I supply 3 alternative mouthpieces: nanxiao_shaku is a shakuchachi mouthpiece. It makes the sound more haunting and louder with more overtones, while the original mouthpiece gives a more quite, very full and beautiful sound. Nanxiao_travers is a western style traverse flute mouthpiece, which produces a sound somehow in between the other two mouthpieces. nanxiao_xiao is modeled after a chinese xiao flute, a flute very similar to the nanxiao, but typically longer and it is closed on the upper side with only a small blow hole on the edge. The latter one is in my opinion most easy to play and very expressive.

The mouthpiece needs some polishing. The blowing edge is the outer triangular edge of the notch. Eventually, it needs some sharpening with polishing paper or a sharp knife. I usually also cut away some material on the inner edges of the notch to make more oscillating air enter the flute body and this helps a lot to produce a louder sound. 
A problem I found with all 3D printed flutes I made so far is that it is somewhat difficult to blow the lowest one or two notes. For these the air in the body has to move over a large distance and the roughness of the inner wall causes too much friction for these notes to sound properly. To avoid this it is essential to polish the inner wall by wrapping some polishing paper around a stick until the notes start ringing properly. I have printed different flutes with different base tones by scaling the size up or down from the bass to soprano range and all of them sound great. I achieved the best sound results with PLA filament filled with either glass particles or organic materials such as coffee or wood. The printed versions have their own character, but they do sound in their own sense as good as my wooden original.

comments.text: very nice flutes. so is there a joint to print or am im not understanding correctly? do i need other parts from a shop to make this work if i were to print it? i truly love the sound of woodwind instruments. if these 3d printed can produce the full rich sound as you say id love to play with one, thanks also i didn't see a reed type mouthpiece how doe this work?
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text:
Since the flute is quite long, I cut it in 7 pieces. Piece 2 to 7 need to be glued together. Any kind of epoxy glue can do it, just make sure that there are no air leaks. Piece 1 is the mouthpiece which produces the sound, and I have made a joint between piece 1 and piece 2 so that the flute can be tuned.
No you don't need anything else to make them sound and they are perfectly tuned. You have to cover the hole at the end of the mouthpiece with your lower lip and blow like on a travers flute over the outer edge of the nodge. This requires a bit of practice, just like with a western travers flute, except that the blow hole is at the end and not on the side of the flute body. I also supply two alternative mouthpieces which are exchangeable. If you use the travers flute mouthpiece you turn the flute into a travers flute.
Here is a video of a very good taiwanese player: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UebiXgyZZv4
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xiao_(flute)
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.author: Caran

comments.text: Well, I needed weeks to be able to play my first (non-3D-printed) Xiao properly, it is not easy. However, I have already printed 9 of these flutes in different sizes and they are all highly playable. Make sure that you cover the upper cylindrical opening entirely with your lower lip, so that only the triangular notch is open. Hold the flute at around 45 degrees to your body so that the airstream hits the outer edge of the notch. It is probably necessary to sharpen the edge, you may use a sharp knife, but make sure you do not destroy the outer edge. It also helps to remove the edges on the inner part of this notch so that the oscillating air can enter the flute body more easily. I have designed another 'Xiao' headpiece which is much more easy to play and produces a loader sound. I will upload it tomorrow, maybe try this instead. The headpiece alone does not consume too much material, this is why I made them interchangeable.
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: Hi, could you please provide close-up image of working nanxiao mouthpiece.  I am finding it difficult to get a sound out even after sharpening edge (not a musician myself). Anyway that I can send you a photo of mine for comment? Otherwise flute looks great.
comments.author: Caran

comments.text: that sounds great i will try it out as soon as it is up for download. also have you made all your notes work? i can only get three to play on the modern flute i printed.
comments.author: Caran

comments.text:
I uploaded it, it is called 'nanxiao_xiao.stl'.
Yes, I can play 2 octaves on them. From my experience there are two reasons why a 3d printed flute does not sound properly. The first thing is that the blow edge where the tone is generated must be sharp. This is not the case when they come out of the printer. I always sharpen them and cut away any edge inside that may prevent the oscillating air to enter the flute body. The second reason is friction inside the flute body. The inner surface of a 3D printed flute is usually quite rough. Especially for the low notes the air has to travel a long way when it oscillates within the flute body and friction on the inner walls will suppress the sound. Wrap some polishing paper around a stick and polish the inside well and the low notes will sound better. This is especially a problem on flutes with a narrow body, like a western style recorder. You may even consider to put some varnish on the inside. Apart from this, you must make sure that the body has no air leaks, put some flute grease of vasoline on the joint. In addition, the more infill it has the better for the sound, but I am usually fine with 30% infill. I made some with some glass loaded PLA filament, this is quite heavy and hard and gives a very beautiful sound (I have no affiliation with this company and no intention to do publicity for them, but the material is perfect for flutes: http://www.3domusa.com/glass-filled-pla/).
comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: thanks so much i plan to use your tips. and thanks for the update of new glass filled pla. i am always looking for new ideas and way to improve things, im sure this will help me do just that. your very kind, thanks again post more musical items soon!
comments.author: Caran

comments.text: My method was fairly tedious. I made a 48 segment helix for the major diameter. Then make two smaller helix for the minor diameters, and connect all the intersecting points to make the profile of one thread. Copy the profile for as many threads as needed. There is a video somewhere on you tube that shows this. The key is to make sure you get a true helical shape when creating a thread.

author: Streetfire_Industries

description.text:
To be able to keep the bed temp up to 110 degrees C I had to make a nice enclosure for my new Solidoodle 3. I used locally bought acrylic glass sheet (Biltema), one sheet of 4 mm thick 400x600 mm and three sheets of 2 mm thick 300x300 mm acrylic sheet for the sides. Sides are held by 10x10x2 mm neodym magnets I had laying around just pressed into the pockets. Update 2013-08-07: New magnetic holder for acrylic glas added for round 10 mm magnets (around 1,8 mm thick from UnitedHobby) it is the part "hinge door 3_mod,stl" file Update 2013-10-30: Short instruction for how many of each part you need.
Printed parts:
lid_corner.stl --> 4 parts
nob_door.stl --> 1 part
hinge_door_1.stl --> 2 parts
hinge_door_2.stl --> 2 parts
hinge_door_3.stl/door_hinge_3_mod.stl -->
6 parts each for the two sides (left/right)
1 part for the top side of the front door
hinge_door_3.stl uses magnets with size 10x10x1,75 mm
hinge_door_3_mod.stl uses magnets that are round with diameter 10 mm and thickness 1,5 mm.
The thickness does not need to spot on but rather thinner then thicker. Plastic sheets needed
The plastic sides are made from 300x300x2 mm thick acrylic sheets and the top sheet is made from a 4 mm thick acrylic sheet. I cut the lidtop and the lid sides from the 4 mm sheet which from the start had the size 400x600 mm. I laid it on top of the SD3 and marked out the top size. I took the rest of the sheet and cut the lid sides so that the 3D printed corner pieces reached down over the SD cube corners. I used M3 Hex screws and lock nuts to mount it all together. The hinge_door_1.stl, hinge_door_2.stl and hinge_door_3.stl parts was mounted on the 2 mm acrylic sheets with a small amount of UHU por glue. I also added rubber lining on the sides and the door to tighten it up and to avoid heat to exit. Enjoy and if there are any questions don't be a stranger ;) Enjoy. Ps. I will add a filament guide and Filament spool holder mounted to the lid later on. I also need to use a 40 W light bulb in the bottom of the enclosure to get to 110 degrees C bed temp. With this temp there is no problem with part not sticking to the bed. Note: I use this temp with ABS plastic

Printed with following temps: Extruder: 195 degrees C
Bed: 105-110 degrees C
Filament: Blue ABS 1,75 mm

comments.text: 3DPrintClean is developing an Odor and Ultrafine Particle filtration attachment for DIY enclosures. Would make a great addition. See http://3dprintclean.com/3dprintclean-scrubber.htm - Disclosure, I am the founder of 3DPrintClean.

title: Modified Bra Beast Plate Leg Section - NO PINS

description.text:
When I printed out a Bra Beast, based off of Theo Jansen's Strandbeest, I found that with PLA the pins were too large and that I needed to reduce the height & width slightly and keep the length the same because PLA is more rigid than ABS.
I found about 92-94% on both axes worked best with a slightly snug fit.  I modified the leg section plate by removing the pins so I would save time and not waste materials since I had to print the pins separately.

Printer:

Dremel Idea Builder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes: 3 shells on my Dremel Idea Builder, each leg section takes 2 hours 33 minutes to print.which is down from the just over 3 hours with the pins. I also increased the speed on the fine setting to 90 mm/.s for printing.

I used Separate Shells in Mesh Mixer to break the STL into separate meshes.  Then I could select each pin and delete it from the model.
Next I used the Export function from the Print screen to get a combined STL file.  It also produced an STL for each individual part.  I'm sure there is a way to avoid the step, but I haven't looked for it yet.

description.text:
Here are relief maps of Martinique and some of the Caribbees. Data was taken from GMTED2010, a USGS data set available from the earth explorer web site. http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/ GMTED2010 is a global elevation data set in geotiff format. A 7.5 arc-second resolution file, 10n090w_20101117_gmted_mea075.tif, was downloaded and converted to "raw" format with Adobe Photoshop. The raw format file contains 14400 rows and 9600 columns of two byte signed integers. A fortran program similar to those in things 118327 and 121275 was used to treat the raw file. Stl files are: st_kitts_nevis.stl 210 x 210 points at 7.5 arc-seconds
guadaloupe.stl 240 x 200 points at 15 arc-seconds
dominica.stl 170 x 240 points at 7.5 arc-seconds
martinique.stl 250 x 260 points at 7.5 arc-seconds
st_lucia.stl 155 x 220 points at 7.5 arc-seconds
st_vincent.stl 150 x 300 points at 7.5 arc-seconds The fortran program that created the openSCAD polyhedron commands is included.

All the stl files can be printed directly on the build platform.  
Martinique is known because of the 1902 Mount Pelee disaster and the story "Ti-Coyo and his Shark" by the Martinquan Clement Richer.  Mount Pelee is the volcano at the northern end of the island.

title: Extruder mit Mehrfachantrieb / Extruder with multidrive

description.text:
Ich hab bei verschiedenen Materialien das Problem, dass mein Bowden-Extruder bei ca. 80%-90% seiner Kraft läuft, die er auf das Filament übertragen kann. Dadurch kann es vorkommen, dass sich das Antriebsrad in das Filament rein gräbt und dann das ganze Modell das gedruckt wird, Müll ist. Es ist sicherlich immer ein grosses Modell, wo das Mistding stecken bleibt :-( Es gibt Extruder wie Sand am Meer, welche über einen Antriebspunkt funktionieren. Aber nur sehr wenige, welche das Filament über mehrere Punkte antreiben. Merkmale, welche ich zu grunde gelegt hab, und nichts gefunden hab:
  • Mind. 2 Antriebe
  • Ein Motor
  • MK7 (ID11mm) Antriebsrad
  • Gefederter Andruck über Maul-Klammern.
    • Dabei ist dann das rausgekommen. Ich habe das noch nicht gedruckt, so dass ich nicht sagen kann, ob alles richtig funktioniert. Wenn Ich eine Fehlermeldung bekomme, korrigiere ich das gern. Materialliste:
  • 5 mm Achse
  • Kugellager ID5; AD16; D6
  • 4x M3x25
  • Zum befestigen 4 x 4mm Schrauben

Google Translate I have on different materials, the problem that my Bowden extruder at about 80% -90% of its strength is running, it can be transferred to the filament. Thereby it can happen that the gears purely digging in the filament and then the whole model is printed that garbage is. There is certainly still a great model, where the crap thing stuck :-( There extruder a dime a dozen, which operate on a point of attack. But very few, which drive the filament over several points. Features which I have taken as a basis:
  • Mind. 2 drives
  • A motor
  • MK7 (ID11mm) drive
  • Sprung pressure over foot brackets.
    • It then came out. I have not been printed yet, so I can not say if it works correctly. If I get an error message, I correct the like.

author: cheffeundwackl

description.text: I designed these parts to help adapt Gear O'Clock to use a craft-store clock movement, add decorations, and cusomize it for the ArtMinds Clock Movement kits sold at Michaels. Here's a whole web store devoted to clock kits, including high-torque movements: http://www.klockit.com/ Review these files and compare the ones in the original Gear O'Clock to select which parts are most appropriate for your 3D printer and your choice of clock movement. (In any case, you will need the numbered tabs from the original Gear O'Clock Thing.) My blog has a detailed, fully-illustrated explanation of the parts at http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2011/10/gear-oclock.html And here's a YouTube Video showing the two new animated versions of Gear O'Clock http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nzn_2I1OYYw To the best of my knowledge all parts can be built on FDM without support. For consistency all units are inches.

Clock Drive Gear slotted NO SUPPORT.stl This drive gear fits directly onto the threaded shaft hour-hand shaft to the craft-store clock mechanism. Slip it onto the shaft and tighten it with the threaded brass ring from the clock kit. Clock Base div4.stl In case the 10 inch wheel is too big for your printer, this version is divided into 4 pieces. The joins are beveled so the drive gear moves smoothly from one section to another, and the numbered tabs act as splices to bridge each joint. Clock Seconds Gear.stl This a decorative cap attaches to the original second-hand from the clock kit, attaching to the shaft through the hole in the Clock Drive Gear. Re-uploaded 17 Oct 2011 to fix orientation for hobby 3D printers. Clock Mechanism Mount cutout.stl The craft store clock movement has a built-in wall hook, so this Mechanism Mount has a cutout to accomodate it. Clock_Mechanism_Mount_Pendulum.stl For clock movement kits with a pendulum, this mount has been enlarged and has openings at the top and bottom to accommodate the built in wall-hook and pendulum associated with Clock Movement Kits that have a powered pendulum. Clock_Gear_Pendulum.stl This is a gear-themed pendulum that hooks onto the pendulum hanger on a Clock Movement kit that has a powered pendulum. Clock_Drive_Gear_r2.stp A CAD representation of the drive gear for customization in case my revisions don't suit your needs...or if you've got some novel ideas to add! Clock_Drive_Gear.dxf is a DXF cross-section of the drive gear for customization, just in case your CAD program can't read the previous STEP file. Also useful if you want to build an accessory with OpenSCAD.

description.text: Tired of having to pass blame using your own finger? Can't afford to hire someone to do it for you? Then the Finger Pointer is for you! Video of blame being assigned at "http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3ENePYE1dg". I saw this somewhere but cannot remember where, or who was the original creator, but this is my PLA rendition of the original idea. Finger Pointer was designed using Sketchup 8, and printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA, using Makerware. UPDATE 1: Uploaded the Sketchup 8 .stl files for the base and lift, and an exploded assembly. If this doesn't help assembling this thing, please feel free to comment and I'll do my best to solve any problems. I'm very sorry for the problems that you've experienced with this thing.

The Finger Pointer can be built to be hand cranked or electrically animated. If your Finger Pointer will be electrically animated, then: 1) Purchase the motor "6VDC 45 RPM Pinky Finger Sized Gear Motor 1" Long x 15/32" x 3/8"" from either amazon.com or directly from http://sciplus.com/p/MICROMOTOR_47952 (this is the same motor I used in the "Marbelvator" design), a coaxial power jack (I used Radio Shack part number 274-1583), and a 6vdc power supply with the appropriate connector to fit the coaxial power jack (I used Radio Shack part number 273-316). 2) Print "Base.stl". Solder wires to motor plus and minus terminals. Slide motor into "Base.stl". Mount coaxial power jack on "Base.stl". Solder motor wires to the coaxial power jack; plus to "center" pin, and minus to "shell" pin. For both hand cranked and electrical animated versions, print the remaining parts and assemble them according to "Assembly.skp". A vise comes in handy to carefully press the components onto "Crank.stl". Some light sanding of "Crank.stl" may ease the force required. After assembly, apply a small drop of light machine oil on the inside of "Guide.stl". Using 60 grit sandpaper, roughen the circumference of both "Eccentric.stl". Place on desk, pointing AWAY from you, then hand crank or plug it in and blame away to your hearts content!

description.text: this is my first trophy invention

Don't ask me to give out the original parametric model. Vr goggles for 5.6" HV056WX1-100 LCD panel. The driver board is a VGA and DVI board with a non functioning DVI, so I have a new and better board on order, and will make a new electronics compartment when I get it. Sorry, I don't know what the current board is called, but it seems to be a common form factor for VGA boards. If your electronics don't fit make your own electronics compartment. It's easy as it's just a rectangular box. The LCD should be stuck to the shoulders of the box using double sided tape. This is the board I ordered: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/1-x-HDMI-VGA-2AV-AUDIO-Controller-Board-For-5-6Inch-TFT-HYUNDAI-HV056WX1-100-HV056WX1/32268599169.html LCD: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/free-shipping-Original-5-6-inch-HV056WX1-100-1280-800-TFT-LCD-LVDS-25pin-screen-display/32322456979.html?spm=2114.01020208.3.1.KsHJy4&ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_3,searchweb201644_3_10001_10002_10005_10006_10003_10004_62_61,searchweb201560_1,searchweb1451318400_6148 I might buy a 2560x1440 resolution board as 1280x800 is too low resolution for 90° FOV. I also might make a version for two 3,5" 640x480 panels for FPV use. I have the panels on order. The mask is comfortable to hold against the face for me, even without padding. I made the nose cutout as big as possible because of my big nose. The lenses are aspheric 2" pocket magnifier lenses and are held in place by the O-rings they come with. Install the lenses with the biggest bulge towards the screen.: http://www.ebay.com/itm/251148139033 Also needs four M4x20 mm screws and four M3x25-30 mm screws, preferably countersunk M3 screws.
Notes: Print in the orientation they come. The lens holder assembly needs support around the base.

description.text:
The solution for bed leveling with no loss in bed height It is very simple yet very effective it is simply two hollowed out shafts that slide inside each other that the screw can pass through each shaft has a 2mm base or cap for support the key thing here is that there is an internal spring that pushes the two shafts apart.
as can barely be seen in the images The problem before with just springs is that they generally have no horizontal support and could allow the bed to shift as the bolt tips the intermingled shafts help prevent this. This was actaully but together with a spring from a pen but was designed for use with a spring from MCMaster-Carr but could be used with similar springs else where.
The important specs:
Item: Metric Compression Spring
Material: Music Wire,
Length uncompressed: 19mm Overall,
Diameter: 9mm OD,
wire width: 1.00mm Wire-WOW nice and thick should make it stable horizontally
compressed height: 7.5mm
so fully compressed the height will be 11mm current height is 12mm it expands about 8-9mm but you should not need nearly this amount.
The McMaster Carr product number is: 94125K633
and the link is: http://www.mcmaster.com/#94125k633/=p19bik the cost for the springs is just over $10 for a 5 pack but should be extremely stable in the horizontal plane The current shaft will have to be removed in order to implement this leveler as the new shafts take its place. Have fun. I am glad that so many people are printing these things out and using them I just added another it is called robolevel7mm.stl , it is very similar to the original. The only difference is the smaller piece only has a 7mm hollowed out section to allow for a 7mm spring as the 9mm may be hard to come by still focus on 1mm wire size and the rest of the specs as close as you can to get optimal use I just uploaded the netfabb repaired version for both groups because I think something happened to the originals as some were having trouble with it, sorry if this caused any inconvenience.

I recentely added the extra nut and washer(in the circle in the last pic) and it now makes the entire thing mush more steady and easier to adjust the main instruction is in the description but I am adding this as well the exploded view is a better way to install it on the rail system the Robo currently uses. Normally the screw/bolt coming through the rail and the original stand off was not menat to be moved so it was simply screwed down tight but when using the bed levelers some times that screw would turn when trying to adjust the locking nut on top so I added a flat washer and an additional nut that goes inside the lower portion of the bed leveler to lock that screw and the lower part of the bed leveler down and keep it all from moving.  That potentially loose screw becomes a locked down stud and the spring then simply rests on top of the nut and makes adjustments very very easy now just a turn of the nut to raise or lower the bed without having to try and get underneath to hold the screwwhile turning the nut.

comments.text: How long are the screw they use now if I remember correctly the fully compressed state of that assembly is about 10-11mm and it had an expansion of 8-9mm so I would assume the length required would be about 15-20mm to give enough room for the nut to be securely on the screw and give some play. Originally they had a spacer that was about the same height about 10-11mm and I modeled this part with that in mind so that the screws could be reused. Bu tit has been a long time and they have made lots of changes. I myself no longer use them because I got the new y axis rails and the autolevel so these are not needed for me but the cost for a slightly longer screw is minimal as compared to the benefit received from these if you are using the older y axis system.

comments.text:
As far as I know my diagram fits most of the printbed setups out
there now the orientation of the screw is pretty muc VERY non critical
in the original setup on the printbed so the ROBO guys may have changed
it although I can not really come up with a reason that really makes
sense on a standard layout other than it makes it more difficult to
install this mod. In a completely static situation it does not matter as
long as it is tight it works but change from that and you will
immediately see the advantage of having the nut on top it is much easier
to tighten or loosen it because the original screw they used would not
rune easily in the rails so in effect it iwas locked in place and the
nuts could loosen or tighten it down VERY easily.
In another
iteration we found that the bolts used could in the newer printers would
spin easilyso it became problematic in any orientation.
That is
why I added the revision to this original mod. Now based on the last
bolt head down configuration I saw this revision made it a VERY stable
platform by following the last diagram you essentially turn what was a
loose screw into a locked in place threaded stud that made it easy to
adjust the nut again. In a nutshell I know thread the bolt from below
through the rail AND the lower printed piece and then lock it in place
with a nut so it will not spin at all the finish the assembly normally.
Putting on the spring and the upper piece and the bed and then
compressing the spring to put the nut on allows for the spring action to
force the bed against the bottom of the nut so tightening or loosening
will raise or lower that point on the bed.
Reversing the orientation should not pose any problem other than you MAY find it
difficult for the head of the bolt too slip into the rail as it usually
did.
ask away if you have any more questions

comments.author: Tesseract

comments.text:
Something is not quite right then it is actually very easy to do
The two parts should easily slide into each other with the spring inside and should be able to be compressed with finger pressure if not something is of in your print as several people are using these without issue.
Procedure
Current: Bed is removed and only rails are present on frame
Step 1 Insert Screw through hole in rail corresponding to the hole in the bed
Step 2 Insert lower half of bed leveler onto screw
Step 2 Place small nut on threads and tighten it down securely -nut should be at the inside bottom of lower bed leveler
Step 3 Repeat 1 - 3 for all remaining holes in rails
At this point you have turned the screw basically into studs and they should not in any way be loose
Step 4 Place spring on threaded area of screw resting it on the nut inside the leveler
Step 5 Place upper bed lever piece on spring screw should just protrude from upper piece so it all stays together
Step 6 Repeat 4-5 for all corners
Step 7 Place bed on levelers aligning the screws with the holes
Step 8 Compress the spring assembly so screw protrudes from hole in bed and place a flat washer on the screw
Step 9 Place locking nut on screw securing it in place--It is a good idea to tighten the screw down so some threads protrude so you will have some area for adjustment
Step Repeat 8-9 for all corners
Adjustment is done based on a readings from a dial indicator and simply turning the lock nut will raise or lower the corner being worked on. The adjust can be done entirely from the top as the first nut put in place locks the screw solid so it should not turn

author: tejawood

description.text:
Ever wanted to print something other than PLA on your MB 5thGen? Having issues with warped edges? Time to put a heated print bed (HPB) on it. MB does not have any options for an HPB so I had to make my own design. I am now able to print perfectly flat using ABS, PET+, and PLA. I am sure it will do others but have not experimented yet. The HPB will easily heat to 110° C. It will use your existing glass plate. Keep in mind that this will NOT be integrated with the MB software. You will have to manually turn off/on the HPB before/after you print. The temperature controller will maintain whatever temperature you set and I also enabled a safety feature so that if the thermocouple fails or a relay fails closed, it will automatically turn off the power supply to prevent a fire. Materials needed:
  • 350w 12-24v DC power supply http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KXV4WH8?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s02
  • PCB heatbed hot plate (i got the one with the LEDs already soldered) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B015369VT6?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s03
  • 12v relay 30/40amp with wiring harness (you only need 1, i bought a 5 pack) http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005HFYE1O?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s02
  • Temperature controller able to go above 100°C http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00OLOGO9M?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01
  • Some 14ga wire
  • 5 amp 120v fuse and holder
  • Heat shrink tubing
  • 120v plug
  • Masking tape
  • Painters tape
  • 2 paint sticks or yard sticks that are 5mm thick (Update: changing to Aluminum strips. May have to adjust clips as they are only 3.5mm thick.)
  • 120v LED Panel mount (to let you know if the power supply is running, not required)
  • SPST panel mount switch (to turn off power to HPB but still leave the control unit on)
  • 110v Power switch ( to turn the HPB and Temp Controller on/off)
  • Plastic or metal enclosure 4x5x6” to hold all components (recommend plastic if you don't have a nibbler to cut metal squares/holes
  • Banana female connectors for the ability to unplug Thermocouple
  • High amperage 12v connector like an XT60 or Dean's for the ability to unplug the HPB.
  • Both of the above connectors are recommended to be able to remove HPB and remove/replace the blue tape.
  • Some soldering skills
  • Some electrical skills
  • Work very slowly and make sure all your connections are 100% correct prior to energizing. This is a lot of power and easy to make mistakes
    • Steps:
    Build temperature controller
  • Get plastic enclosure box and cut out square opening for Temperature Controller
  • Drill holes for the banana plugs, switches, power cables and anything you need in/out of the box
  • Refer to the wiring diagram on how everything ties together
  • Use 14ga wire for anything that will have high current
  • Refer to Inkbird on how the temperature controller operates for the ITC-100RH
  • Be sure to ground your power supply and case if using a metal box
  • Remember you are dealing with 120v in the case. Be careful if operating with case open and any shorts or incorrect wiring
    • Build Heated Print Bed
  • Print 4 clips prior to dismanteling your print bed
    o 100% infil, Standard resolution (200mm)
    o Order of preferance on filament (PET+, ABS,PLA)
  • Remove print bed tray and remove glass
  • Clean glass of all material and finish with an alcohol wipe
  • Store print bed plastic tray. Will no longer need
  • On PCB heater, solder power connections to bottom of PCB (side with the LED connector)
    o Make sure the top is flat even at the solder pads
    o Make sure there is solder going all the way through the PCB to ensure heating elements on top are getting power
  • Cut paint sticks/yard sticks 1x235mm, 2x108mm
    o Maker sure the paint sticks are 5mm thick (homedepot/lowes)
  • Center PCB heating element side (noticable by all the rows of traces on the board) on the glass
  • Tape (masking tape) PCB to glass. Do not wrap tape around edges of glass
  • Bend thermocouple tip 90° and place in center hold of PCB (update: use some hose bib rubber washers taped around the tip to keep in place over time.)
  • Using masking tape, put ~3 layers of tape on thermocouple to hold in center of PCB and provide some insulation
  • Tape (masking tape) wood pieces to PCB as shown in pictures
    o Two shorter pieces are for placing on the front side with space for the thermocouple wiring
  • Cover top of glass with Blue Painters tape. Wipe with an alcohol wipe. This creates a fantastic surface for all filaments. Wipe gets rid of any residue or grease on the surface.
  • Install new heater print bed on bed platform
  • Install clips starting top first and snap at the bottom of the platform edge
  • Admire your creation
  • Perform level process based on your printer. On the MB 5th gen, I first start with an auto level then finish with a manual level.
    o Turn off printer
    o Manually turn bed Z rod to move the print bed to within a couple mm of the print head
     Use a paper towel or something as this has grease on it
     You will want to recoat the rod after you are done with grease as this should be done periodically anyways
    o Manually move the print head to the center of the print bed
    o Use a business card and bring print bed up to the thickness of the business card. You should be able to move the business in an out with minimal friction
    o Move the print head to the front center
    o Measure with business card again. Adjust front/back knob to same friction as center
    o Move print head to rear center, measure and adjust. Do this several times to get front and back as close as possible
    o Move print head to right center, then left center and adjust the left/right knob until the exact same
    o Do this process several times to get the entire surface of the print bed the same height.
    o Keep in mind that the glass may not be 100% flat and that the print head rods may also not be 100% flat. I ALWAYS print with a raft on the MB to eliminate as much unlevel as possible
  • Once you have everything setup and operational, the below settings should get you started. Adjust for your brand of filament. This entire setup also helps in eliminating any variances you may be seeing by your room temperature. Before I had to put the printer in a closet with a space heater as my house was too cold causing a lot of warping. Now with the HPB I don't have to use a space heater, my prints are near 100% flat and I am able to do stronger filaments.
  • Filament starting temperature (all numbers in C)
    o ABS HPB 110° Extruder 235° Speed 90% (Infill,inset, raft)
    o PET+ HPB 70° Extruder 245° Speed 50%
    o PLA HPB 50° Extruder 215° Speed 100%

Infill:

comments.text: How fast is it cycling?  I've been using mine for about a year and it consistently cycles about every 45-60 seconds once warmed up to temperature.  One thing to check if it is cycling fast is to check the dead band on the temp controller.  The deadband was a bit small for mechanical relays on mine which is fully customizable. I've thought about going solid state since they are so cheap now but have had zero issues.  Since it is mechanical relay based, you'd want there to be a dead band of about +/- 2° whereas with solid state the cycling is not an issue.  The dead band is configured in the controller so that if you set the bed for 65°C, it will turn off at 67°C and back on at 63°C .  Look for the setting to select the delta° or Hysteresis band for the high and low temperature points.  For the Ink-bird, it uses a self-tuning capability.  My settings away from defaults are at: HIAL=120° (sets alarm and turns off power supply if the heat bed exceeds), CtrL=0 (Originally did CtrL=3 to do self tuning), M50=71, P=284, t=110.  Otherwise everything is at default.

Set each of the below: HIAL=120° (sets alarm and turns off power supply if the heat bed exceeds), CtrL=0, M50=71, P=284, t=110. See if this helps any. The manual for the controller is at http://manualzz.com/doc/6563762/user-manual-itc-100-pid-temperature-controller.

comments.text: Could be a couple things.  How do you have the temp probe connected to the print bed?  Is it possible that it is sitting on a heater element or is it in the hole of the heater?    is the temp probe the right type "K" thermocouple?  Have you checked that the temp of the bed shown on the controller is accurate via an infrared therm or something.  The error sounds like the probe is responding too quick as in it is seeing the temperature of the heater, not the print bed which would cause it to do something like you are describing.

comments.text: vbonilla - Thank you for the interest in the MB HPB.  In the original post, I included all the components required.  What I have added since building this is a 110v digital timer so that I can set the HPB to run for 15/30/45/60/75 minute increments depending on the print I am doing.  I have not switched to aluminum yet and are still using the yard sticks.  I have been printing almost nonstop with up to 110° HPB temps.  ZERO issues with the wood as I have checked several times and the wood looks brand new.  For test prints I still print in PLA and all final prints I have been almost exclusively printing in ABS or PETG.  I create my own quad drone designs and have found ABS to be the most resilient.  The MB 5thGen is an amazing printer as I am the only one at an office with multiple printer brands that has near perfect success with 3D prints.  If there is something more specific I can assist with, please let me know.

title: Parts cup for a Prusa i3

description.text:
I saw the original design (all credit to "Bradley") but realised that it didn't quite do what I wanted - I needed something a bit larger, and also wanted it to fit over the 6mm plate of my Prusa i3.  In addition, I took on board one of the comments from the original design and made the cup hemispherical, to make it easier to pick out items.
The OpenSCAD file is incredibly basic, and easy to modify if you want a parts cup of a different size. Just bear in mind that if you change one parameter you will probably need to change one or two others!
I made mine in ABS at 0.2mm layer height with a brim, but just about any material will work, at any layer height - just pick any set-up that you are happy to use.  I didn't use any support as I'm happy to bridge a 6mm gap, but choose "support" if you're not so confident (or reckless!).

comments.text: Would you be willing to tell us how you designed these?  Are there any tutorials you would recommend?
comments.author: rjwern2

comments.text: I just modeled them in 3Ds Max. Not sure what to tell you here, I have 10+ years experience in modeling so making them was nothing complex for me. When you search for something like "low poly character modeling" you should find lots of tutorials. To give you some insight: most are started from a box and then lots of vertices pushing around and adding loops. Verts are then welded wherever the mesh can get more low res. They are modeled with symmetry in a T-pose and then rigged and posed. Posing is very tricky when you want to print them without support. So you have to do things like putting a hand on a leg. I also made me a simple shader that would highlight me faces which are angled less then 30 degrees and then pushed verts around again to make those angles better for printing without support. As a last step I took them in Zbrush to merge it all together to one solid mesh. This is important to get thing like a overlapping hand on a leg merged.

use an 8mm threaded rod, around 3/4th a foot long (cutoff scrap from making printer), grind one end of it into a semi pointed code (not sharp), then take a dremel and cut lines into the cone going long ways into the threaded rod, around 5mm in. After that, just put a nut on the end that isnt grinded down, and slide it through the handle, then attach a washer and nut onto threaded rod, and tighten it down so it's very tight, so nothing will move. I use it for screwing into the holes on printed bearings and parts for when Im making my reprap printer parts, for when they wont fit the rods. Just screw it in, and it'll cut into the plastic that is too small making way for the screw rod, which will keep screwing the rod in till the part hits the nut/washer on the handle, then if you keep turning it, it'll clean out all of the extra plastic that went between the threads acting as a drill bit almost, but you have more control over it. Then after the screw is cleaned out and you can move it somewhat, just use the threads on the screw rod as like a file for the holes to make them exactly how you need them to be so everything slides/fits perfectly. Mine looks rough from excessive usage, and I have the two nuts in the center there, they arent perminant, they're just there because I was cleaning printable pla lm8uu bearings, trying to get the raft stuff off of them from the first layer. description.text:
Thermostat adapter which allows using modern electronic thermostats with M30x1,5 threads on (older) M28x1,5 radiator mounts.
The adapter consists of two parts. The pin has been designed with a length of 20 mm (4.4 mm diameter). Different thermostats/radiators may require a different length.
The adapter has to be printed in ABS (or any other material with a high melting point). PLA gets too soft when the radiator heats up.

comments.text: Hi. Do you print in PLA or ABS? I have designed similar adapter to fit M30x1.5 thermostats over Danfoss RA mounts. comments.author: antonveretenenko

comments.text: Hi, printed in ABS, should have added this in the description in the first place. With this part I did not have any warping issues (build plated heated to 110 degrees + glue on blue tape) you may want to give yours another try. PLA is getting quite soft at temperatures around 60 degrees, which radiators can reach and therefore is not suited for such adapters. ABS works fine.
